title: Quiz 4: HIV/AIDS Progression & Clinical Stages
topicName: Unit Six: STIs and HIV AIDS
description: Assess your knowledge on how HIV progresses from acute infection to AIDS, including the specific WHO clinical stages.

questions.question: The ___BLANK___ period is the time between HIV infection and when antibodies are detectable, usually lasting 3 to 6 months.
questions.explanation: The 'window period' is critical because the person is infectious but tests negative.
questions.hint: It's like looking through a glass but not seeing the virus yet.

questions.question: Arrange the stages of HIV progression in the correct chronological order:
questions.explanation: 1. Acute (flu-like) -> 2. Asymptomatic (latent) -> 3. Symptomatic (minor infections) -> 4. AIDS (severe infections).
questions.hint: Start with the initial infection event.

questions.question: Match the clinical condition to the correct WHO Stage:
questions.explanation: Stage 1: Asymptomatic. Stage 2: Minor mucocutaneous (Herpes Zoster). Stage 3: Oral Thrush, TB. Stage 4: AIDS defining illnesses (KS).
questions.hint: Higher stages mean more severe conditions.

questions.question: What is 'Acute Seroconversion Syndrome'?

options.text: Flu-like symptoms experienced shortly after initial infection

questions.explanation: Some newly infected people experience fever, chills, and rash (flu-like) during the acute infection stage.
questions.hint: It happens right at the start.

questions.question: Which of the following are characteristic of Stage 4 (AIDS)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: PGL is Stage 1. Minor rashes are Stage 2. Wasting, PCP, and Encephalopathy are Stage 4 (AIDS defining).

questions.question: During the Latent/Asymptomatic period (Stage 2), the person is NOT infectious and cannot transmit the virus.
questions.explanation: False. Throughout the latent period, the person stays infected and infectious, even if they feel healthy.
questions.hint: Can a person with no symptoms still pass on the virus?

questions.question: Why is HIV testing in children below 18 months difficult using standard antibody tests?

options.text: They may retain maternal antibodies, giving a false positive
The virus hides in the bone marrow

questions.explanation: Babies acquire antibodies from the mother. A positive test might reflect the mother's antibodies, not the baby's infection.
questions.hint: Whose antibodies are in the baby's blood?

questions.question: What is the common term for 'Persistent Generalised Lymphadenopathy' seen in Stage 1?
questions.explanation: PGL stands for Persistent Generalised Lymphadenopathy.

questions.question: What is the average time between HIV infection and the diagnosis of AIDS (if untreated)?
questions.explanation: According to the CDC, the average time is 8-10 years.
